title: Exhibition Checklist
publication_title: James Ensor: The Temptation of Saint Anthony
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body">Focused on Ensor’s paintings from before and after he made The Temptation, this gallery shows how the artist’s imagery changed course dramatically between the 1880s and the 1890s. Although the works reveal a constant interest in light, color, and technical experimentation, their subject matter varies wildly. It is hard to believe that the artist of the early and conventional Rooftops of Ostend also produced the broken sky of the Adam and Eve Expelled from Paradise. Most unsettling of all, perhaps, are the grotesque carnival scenes Ensor made toward the end of this period. Masked faces leer in lurid colors and skeletons brandish weapons in works that tread a fine line between humor and terror.

It is clear that, between 1885 and 1890, Ensor’s art underwent a deep transformation. During these turbulent years, against a backdrop of social and political changes in Belgium, the artist suffered considerable personal difficulties. The works here provide a visual summary of the extraordinary artistic evolution that took place over this painful period.

Ensor was born and raised in the Belgian port of Ostend; its constantly changing skies, by turns melancholy and luminous, were a frequent theme in his art. Despite his fondness for the town, however, he remained something of an outsider. While his Flemish mother helped to run a family souvenir shop, his father was an unpopular Englishman, unemployed and alcoholic.

The economy and the mood of Ostend fluctuated with the seasons. A tourist population coexisted with the locals, and extremes of wealth and poverty were painfully obvious. Social tensions were even more pronounced in Brussels, the bilingual (French- and Dutch-speaking) Belgian capital, where Ensor went to study. Clashes between its working-class population and the authorities were frequent. The artist was quick to capture the unrest in both Ostend and Brussels, satirizing the king, the government, and other authorities in his art.

In The Temptation, beneath an impossibly blue sky, crowds gather and protestors march; but in the works here the extremes of Ensor’s love of and disdain for his homeland are even more apparent.

From 1877 to 1880, Ensor attended the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Brussels. In later years he criticized the experience, but it proved to have a profound impact on his creative development. Importantly, his attendance at the academy allowed him to meet other artists, including those he would join in creating the exhibition society Les XX (Les Vingt; The Twenty), a new forum for the display of avant-garde art. It also exposed him to the Old Masters; indeed, historic works of art would provide a constant source of inspiration throughout his career.

Although his copies after Francisco de Goya, Frans Hals, and Édouard Manet appear in this gallery, Ensor did not look to European art alone. He also admired popular Japanese prints, which his family sold to tourists in their souvenir shop. Japanese art featured in several exhibi­tions in Brussels in the 1880s where—like the work of Ensor and his contemporaries—it sometimes baffled the press. One journalist, attacking The Temptation in 1889, observed, that “James Ensor has thrown himself completely into intransigent Japonisme.” To this critic, the work of the audacious young artist was as incomprehensible as art from a distant land.

Like many avant-garde artists in the late nineteenth century, as he began his career Ensor took his subject matter from contemporary middle-class life. Rather than depict dramatic social or political events, he elevated the domestic interior, celebrating the kind of environment in which a letter or a piece of music could have a profound effect. His family served as models for many of these tightly composed, slightly claustro­phobic scenes.

Painting such interiors was not an easy route to success. Though these images may seem conventional now, they inspired great controversy at the time. Reviewers found particular fault with Ensor’s Oyster Eater, arguing that its monumental size was at odds with its banal subject matter and that the artist had left it unfinished in spots.

With hindsight, however, it seems that the negative reactions simply encouraged the artist. They led him to distrust the critics, to believe in his own talent, and to develop independent ambitions. These lessons would prove vital to Ensor. Without them, he could not have created his monumental Temptation.

Bringing the lessons of his early work to bear on his exploration of new concerns, Ensor created The Temptation of Saint Anthony in 1887 and 1888. Exorcising both public and private anxieties, the artist developed a complex composition made up of fifty-one sketchbook sheets and folios (two-page sheets), where reality and fantasy clash and compete for attention.

In the center of the image is the kneeling figure of Saint Anthony, a fourth-century hermit who famously resisted the allure of sinful visions through prayer and fasting. Above his head, crowned in a military helmet, a sorrowful Christ appears in the clouds. To the left and right of the saint are crowds of contemporary and historical figures. These groupings are sometimes comic, sometimes frightening; a band of motley musicians bombards the saint with song while blood from a nearby slaughter spills freely. As Ensor worked, he delighted in the unfolding chaos. “I’ve added a few hundred more figures: ghastly dev­ils, horrible animals, revolting and obscene monsters,” he explained in a letter to his friend Mariette Rousseau. “I am very pleased.”

In making The Temptation, the artist combined popular and sophisti­cated references, creating a work that challenges cultural hierarchies. The use of newly invented colored pencils on a scale usually reserved for grandiose paintings reinforces the subversive spirit of the drawing. Like a wandering dream, which sometimes strays into nightmarish territory, The Temptation soothes and startles in turn.

In 1885 Ensor began work on a series of important drawings that anticipated The Temptation in scale and subject matter. He called them The Visions: The Aureoles of Christ or the Sensibilities of Light. The display in this gallery unites them for the first time in North America, respecting the narrative sequence Ensor set out in the exhibition catalogue for Les XX in 1887, where they were first shown.

Not only an exploration of the different atmospheric qualities of light, but also an analogy of the artist’s creative suffering, The Visions relays biblical events in intensely personal ways. Borrowing heavily from Rembrandt, Ensor depicted Christ as a mortal: a lonely individual, adored and then ostracized, left to the mercy of the crowd. The artist identified strongly with his misunderstood protagonist; he felt isolated frequently, and he often argued with his art world peers.

The formal qualities of Ensor’s drawings further emphasize their ephemeral character. By using mostly large sheets of paper instead of sturdier canvas supports, Ensor made works that seem transient and vulnerable. While The Visions—made with chalk, pencil, or charcoal—convey light, their delicate tonality changes with shifting viewing con­ditions. Here, in this darkened room, they invite quiet contemplation.

To late-ninteenth-century Europeans, the story of Saint Anthony was a familiar one, played out in popular and intellectual arenas alike. Though the tale was ostensibly one of a fourth-century hermit saint who resisted corrupting visions through prayer, it had long served artists as a means to depict controversial or fantastic imagery. Accordingly, in the examples seen here, invented demonic beasts keep company with lifelike naked bodies. The viewer, like the saint, is in turn shocked and seduced.

Ensor may not have been familiar with all of the variations of the story seen in this room, but given his enduring fascination with the subject, they place his version in context. It is clear that some provided literal sources of inspiration; one of Ensor’s letters refers to the “stunning devilry” he saw in The Temptation of Saint Anthony by printmaker Jacques Callot, for instance, while the dreamlike atmosphere of Gustave Flaubert’s book of the same name seems also to have made an impression.

In addition to his interest in Saint Anthony, Ensor also identified with Jesus, often combining his own features with those of Christ or depicting himself in pseudo-biblical scenarios. As frequently, however, he included a touch of self-deprecating humor. The artist saw the absurdities in his own dilemmas as much as he satirized those of the contemporary world

The people nearest to Ensor had a significant impact on his art. They provided him with financial, moral, and artistic support, and even served as his models.

Ensor’s aunt and mother ran a souvenir shop on a major street in Ostend. The family lived above the store, and Ensor kept a studio in its attic. He had a younger sister, Mitche, and his grandmother was also a frequent visitor to the house. But, as much as he depended on the women in his family, Ensor was fonder still of his father: an unem­ployed Englishman who spent periods of time in an asylum, struggling with alcoholism, before dying prematurely in 1887.

Profound grief, compounded by the loss of his maternal grandmother earlier that year, was surely one of the factors at play as Ensor created The Temptation. His own poor health also had an impact. Fortunately, the artist found comfort in the Hannon-Rousseau family, with whom he had bonded while studying in Brussels. The painter Theo Hannon had been a fellow student; his sister, a mycologist (plant biologist) named Mariette, married Ernest Rousseau, a teacher of natural sciences at the university in Brussels. The couple had a young son, Ernest Rousseau junior, whom Ensor treated like a sibling. Shared interests, humor, and affection abound in the images the artist made for and of these close friends.
